newsitem.title: UK: UK's Ofwat eyes possible changes to tariff basket.
newsitem.headline: UK's Ofwat eyes possible changes to tariff basket.

text.p: Britain's water industry watchdog Ofwat suggested changes to the way charges can change year-on-year in a consultation paper published on Thursday.
Ofwat head Ian Byatt said that within a basket which is used to calculate tariffs, one group of customers should not be expected to subsidise others, a process known as "rebalancing."
He said that charges should be more directly linked to costs and said the review was "a key step in the next review of price limits," due by the end of the century.
Ofwat also suggested that large industrial users should be taken out of the basket calculation and that there should not be a change to separate price limits for water and for sewerage services.

Ofwat also said that the difference in costs between metered and unmetered bills "should be no greater than the extra costs of providing a metered supply," which it put currently at no more than 27 stg.
Ofwat also suggested the possibility of introducing measures such as peak-time tariffs to ensure costs more closely matched demand.
Ofwat said responses to the document should be made by July 18.
